lines.text: Nice thing about you, Joe, is that you can sound like a liberal, but at heart you're an American

Power is not a toy we give to good children. It is a weapon. And the strong man takes it and uses it. If you don't go down there and beat Joe Cantwell to the floor with this very dirty stick, then you've got no business in the big league. Because if you don't fight, the job is not for you. And it never will be.
There have been moments when I have questioned your methods.
Well, you have to fight fire with fire, Mr. President.
And the end justifies the means?
Well, yes, sir. Yes. That is what I believe.
Well, son, I have news for you about both politics and life... and may I say the two are exactly the same thing? There are no ends, Joe, only means...
Major Bascomb... do I understand, by the way you are slowly beating around the bush, that Joe Cantwell is what we used to call a dee-generate?
Yes, sir. That's just what I'm saying.
I don't believe it. No man with that awful wife and those ugly children could be anything but normal.
I don't understand you.
I know you don't. Because you have no sense of responsibility towards anyone or anything. And that is a tragedy in a man, and a disaster in a president.
T.T. Claypoole has all the characteristics of a dog except loyalty.

[to reporters]
And I am happy, of course, the best man won.
Y'know, it's not that I object to your being a bastard, don't get me wrong there. It's your being such a stupid bastard that I object to.
In those days we poured God over everything like ketchup.
You're not crazy, are you?
Any man that wants to be President is crazy.

[Slyly]
You know, those rumors about you and lady friends... they won't do you a bit of harm.
I never pass a mirror, I don't look in it. I wonder why?
As someone sooner or later is bound to say, 'politics makes strange bedfellows.'
I was hoping it wouldn't be you.
Bill, do you believe in God?
Do I? Well, I was confirmed in the Episcopal Church.
Hell, I'm a Methodist, and I'm still asking. Do you believe in God? Do you believe in a day of judgement, a hereafter?
No. I believe in us, I believe in man.

[in response to reporter's question 'do you think people mistrust intellectuals like you in politics?']
Intellectual, you mean I wrote a book? Well, as Bertrand Russell said, people in a democracy tend to think they have less to fear from a stupid man than an intelligent one. I think it's the other way around. I think it's the stupid man.

[to William Russell]
Time was, when you rich boys liked to play games like polo. Now you play politics.

[to William Russell]
You're a very superior man, Bill, the kind we don't often find in politics.

[to William Russell]
Well, son, you've got such a good mind, that sometimes you get so busy thinking how complex everything is, that important problems don't get solved.

[speaking of Mrs. Gamadge]
The only known link between the NAACP and the Ku Klux Klan.
You are not the ideal candidate for women.
Which women do you have in mind?
The women don't like you trying to be funny all the time.
Oh, no. It is a flaw, I agree.

They want a regular kind of man, like, well, like General Eisenhower. With that nice smile. And he's not pushy or aggressive, or any of those things we women don't like about men. He was just grand... Just don't try to be smart aleck and talk over our poor heads.
Is there anything more indecent than the human smile? All those predatory teeth reminding us of our animal descent.
